value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">31</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The Elizabethan audience were not readers. They had to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">draw in the play as they sat or stood at the playhouse,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">through their ears, through their eyes. There was no book</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of 
            <choice>
              <sic>thee</sic>
              <corr>the</corr>
            </choice> words. They could not dxxxx deepen the impression,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">chew it over, and compare it, at a <del hand="ms">
            <choice>
              <sic>atble</sic>
              <corr>table</corr>
            </choice></del> in a private room.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">This perhaps 
            <choice>
              <sic>exp;ains</sic>
              <corr>explains</corr>
            </choice> the scarcity of Elizabethan</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">criticism; and the general nature of what <add hand="ms">[certain?]</add> there is.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>Bioth</sic>
              <corr>Both</corr>
            </choice> <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-psid" key="Sidney, Philip">Sidney</rs> and <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-bjon" key="Jonson, Ben">Ben Jonson</rs> deal with the 
            <choice>
              <sic><add hand="ms" place="inline">g</add>neral</sic>
              <corr>general</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">not with the 
            <choice>
              <sic>particualr</sic>
              <corr>particular</corr>
            </choice>; with the rules of 
            <choice>
              <sic>compsition</sic>
              <corr>composition</corr>
            </choice>,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">not with 
            <choice>
              <sic>t e</sic>
              <corr>the</corr>
            </choice> details of one play or poem in 
            <choice>
              <sic>partciualr</sic>
              <corr>particular</corr>
            </choice>.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It accounts too for the long pause <add hand="ms" place="above">between [sixteenth? seventeenth?] & the 18th centuries</add> when the plays of</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wsha" key="Shakespeare, William"><choice>
              <sic>Shakepaere</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice></rs> even hang suspended and unrealised. It was only</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">when <add hand="ms" place="above">they had to [wait?]</add> they were printed and the book of the words lay in many</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">private rooms txxxx <add hand="ms" place="above">before they</add> received their other life from</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the reader. Much that was lost in the 
            <choice>
              <sic>playhous e</sic>
              <corr>playhouse</corr>
            </choice> was</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">discovered in the private room. But much has also been lost <add hand="ms" place="inline">, when the <!--come back to this --></add></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">We have lost the sound of the spoken word; all that the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">sight of the actors body gives through the eye to the mind.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">We have lost too the sense of being part of the audience.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">We miss a thousand shades that the 
            <choice>
              <sic>darmatistconveyed</sic>
              <corr>dramatist conveyed</corr>
            </choice>by inflection of voice, by gesture, by the 
            <choice>
              <sic>palcing</sic>
              <corr>placing</corr>
            </choice> of</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the actors 
            <choice>
              <sic>vbodies</sic>
              <corr>bodies</corr>
            </choice>. This can still be tested, at least with</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Shakespeare, by 
            <choice>
              <sic>comapring</sic>
              <corr>comparing</corr>
            </choice> whxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxx our impression</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">xmxmxmxmxmxxx after seeing the 
            <choice>
              <sic>p ay</sic>
              <corr>play</corr>
            </choice> with our</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">impression after reading the play. But as the modern actor</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">inevitably imports much that is of his own day, but foreign</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to 
            <choice>
              <sic>Shshakespeare</sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice>, there is still something sunk beyond</l>
